title: Lee Aaker
text:
Lee William Aaker (September 25, 1943 – April 1, 2021) was an American child actor, producer, carpenter, and ski instructor known for his appearance as Rusty of "B-Company" in the 1950s television program "<a href="The%20Adventures%20of%20Rin%20Tin%20Tin">The Adventures of Rin Tin Tin</a>". He was the final surviving cast member of the series. In 1952, Lee Aaker appeared in "Desperate Search" with <a href="Howard%20Keel">Howard Keel</a> and <a href="Keenan%20Wynn">Keenan Wynn</a>.
Early years.
Aaker's mother, Mrs. Myles Wilbour, was the owner of a dancing school in Los Angeles. (Another source says that she "ran a children's theatre academy" and that when Aaker was 4, she had him "singing and dancing at local clubs.")
Film.
On television as a young child, he started appearing uncredited at the age of 8 in films such as "<a href="The%20Greatest%20Show%20on%20Earth%20%28film%29">The Greatest Show on Earth</a>" (1952) and "<a href="High%20Noon">High Noon</a>" (1952). He quickly moved to featured status by the end of that year.
He showed talent as the kidnapped Indian "Red Chief" in a segment of the film "<a href="O.%20Henry%27s%20Full%20House">O. Henry's Full House</a>" (1952) and another kidnap victim as the son of scientist <a href="Gene%20Barry">Gene Barry</a> in "<a href="The%20Atomic%20City">The Atomic City</a>" (1952).
In 1953, he co-starred in the <a href="John%20Wayne">John Wayne</a> <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> classic "<a href="Hondo%20%28film%29">Hondo</a>" (1953) as the <a href="curious">curious</a> <a href="blond">blond</a> son of homesteader <a href="Geraldine%20Page">Geraldine Page</a>.
He also appeared in other film styles such as the "<a href="film%20noir">film noir</a>" thriller "<a href="Jeopardy%20%28film%29">Jeopardy</a>" (1953) with <a href="Barbara%20Stanwyck">Barbara Stanwyck</a>, the horse opera drama "<a href="Arena%20%281953%20film%29">Arena</a>" (1953) with <a href="Gig%20Young">Gig Young</a>, and the comedies "<a href="Mister%20Scoutmaster">Mister Scoutmaster</a>" (1953) with <a href="Clifton%20Webb">Clifton Webb</a> and "<a href="Ricochet%20Romance">Ricochet Romance</a>" (1954) with <a href="Marjorie%20Main">Marjorie Main</a>.
Television.
In 1953-54, Aaker was among the many child actors who auditioned for the role of "Jeff Miller" on the original 1954 "<a href="Lassie%20%281954%20TV%20series%29">Lassie</a>" series, which later aired as "Jeff's Collie". That role went to <a href="Tommy%20Rettig">Tommy Rettig</a>. Two weeks later, Aaker won the role of "Rusty" on "The Adventures of Rin-Tin-Tin", co-starring <a href="James%20Brown%20%28Rin%20Tin%20Tin%29">James Brown</a> (1920–1992) as <a href="Lieutenant">Lieutenant</a> Ripley "Rip" Masters. 
Aaker and Rettig were friends, and both shows were popular with audiences. The two actors and the two star dogs appeared together in a photograph used on the cover of the July 2, 1955 issue of "<a href="TV%20Guide">TV Guide</a>".
Later years.
Aaker told a newspaper reporter that when he reached the age of 21, he was paid a $10,000 lump sum () by the studio that produced "Rin Tin Tin" "and he spent the rest of the '60s traveling around the world 'as sort of a flower child.'" Unable to find work as an adult actor, Aaker got involved as a producer and later worked as a carpenter.
Personal life.
In the late 1960s, Aaker was married to Sharon Ann Hamilton for two years. He resided in <a href="Mammoth%20Lakes%2C%20California">Mammoth Lakes, California</a> for many years and was the first adaptive sports instructor for Disabled Sports Eastern Sierra at Mammoth Mountain. 
According to <a href="Paul%20Petersen">Paul Petersen</a>, an advocate for former child actors, Aaker experienced poverty toward the end of his life, and had struggled for years with substance abuse. Petersen said Aaker had suffered a stroke and died in <a href="Maricopa%20County%2C%20Arizona">Maricopa County, Arizona</a>, near the city of <a href="Mesa%2C%20Arizona">Mesa</a>, on April 1, 2021, and was listed as an "indigent decedent". Petersen was arranging Aaker's burial.
Recognition.
In 2005, Aaker won the <a href="Golden%20Boot%20Awards">Golden Boot Award</a> as "Kids of the West".
